title: 114_hr5910
content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Group includes the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes as chairperson and senior representatives selected by the Undersecretary. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury includes the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes as chairperson and senior representatives from various offices and bureaus of the Department. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury includes key offices like the Office of Foreign Assets Control and the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. The Group conducts contingency planning for imposing economic sanctions rapidly under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury conducts contingency planning for imposing economic sanctions rapidly under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act based on considerations like vulnerability of the foreign country, effectiveness of sanctions, and limited costs to the US economy. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury evaluates the effectiveness of economic sanctions on foreign countries or entities, considering factors like limited costs to the US economy, unilateral vs. multilateral imposition, and the process for lifting sanctions. The Group also reviews each economic sanctions program to improve US economic sanctions policy. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group in the Department of the Treasury evaluates and improves economic sanctions programs administered by the Office of Foreign Assets Control and United States economic sanctions policy. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes coordinates the development of US economic sanctions policy with various government agencies to improve sanctions programs. The Group, consisting of various government agencies, meets at least once a month to ensure equal sharing of information related to US economic sanctions policy. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes or the Secretary of the Treasury can assign Treasury personnel to assist the Group. The Group can receive support staff from the Department of the Treasury to assist in their functions. They are also allowed to consult with experts from academia, research organizations, and the private sector. Additionally, the Group is required to submit annual reports to specific Congressional committees. The Group must submit annual reports to specific Congressional committees detailing contingency planning, identified problems, strategy creation, and interagency overview. The Group's annual reports to Congressional committees must include contingency planning, identified problems, strategy creation, interagency coordination overview, policy expert consultations, sanctions impact assessment, and may also have a classified index and closed briefings for specific committees. The annual reports to Congressional committees must include a comprehensive sanctions impact assessment, evaluating the impact of sanctions on foreign and US economies, as well as behavioral changes, using social scientific research methods. The annual reports to Congressional committees must include a comprehensive sanctions impact assessment on the US and foreign economies, along with behavioral changes. The reports will also detail the social scientific research methods used for each assessment. The reports, excluding classified information, will be publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website. The Department of the Treasury's website provides publicly available information on economic sanctions programs, which may be amended as programs are lifted or modified.
